componentInterface.documentation:
Monaco Editor Cust. Comp. (ccmonacoeditor)

This custom component is based on Microsoft's Monaco Editor. Please check this site as reference for its capabilities: https://microsoft.github.io/monaco-editor/ (opens in a new window).

It can be used inside any kind of container (e.g.: page, panel, dialog, etc) and it runs both in standalone and together with a launchpad.

Launchpad setup

Add the following lines on the launchpad's header:

<script>
    var ccmonacoeditorConfig={
        loaderConfig: {paths:{'vs':'/<path-to>/monaco/min/vs'}},
        loader: "/<path-to>/monaco/min/vs/loader.js"
    }
</script>

WARNING

If your system does not have the monaco editor files, make sure to upload them to a path in the media library (e.g.: /ROOT/libraries/legacy/monaco/vs). In this case, the previous lines should be changed to reflect the new path. Using the example of /ROOT/libraries/legacy/monaco/vs in the media library, then the code will be:​

<script>
    var ccmonacoeditorConfig={
        loaderConfig: {paths:{'vs':'/media/root/libraries/legacy/monaco/min/vs'}},
        loader: "/media/root/libraries/legacy/monaco/min/vs/loader.js"
    }
</script>

IMPORTANT

This setup contrasts with the monaco editor site instructions, because the original setup clashes with some libraries being loaded dynamically. The monaco editor library is now being dynamically loaded only when the component is first used in such a way that it will not clash with other libraries.

Quick start

Use these steps to have a quick and running javascript code editor for your app:

  1. Add the component to your project and give it a unique name (e.g.: Editor);
  2. Set the height and the width properties to "100%";
  3. Open a javascript code tab for the monacoOptionsBuilder initialization event and add the following code:
return {
    value: '/* this is a javascript editor */\n',
    language: 'javascript',
    lineNumbers: "on",
    automaticLayout: true,
    scrollBeyondLastLine: true,
    readOnly: false,
    theme: "vs-dark",
}
Please note that:
  • the property autoInit is defaulted to true - that's the reason why the editor will be created automatically with the example above;
  • if you want to create the code editor manually through the initEditor method, then you need to set autoInit: false;
  • whatever settings you use, it's important that you include automaticLayout: true to make it responsive, otherwise the editor will stay with the same dimensions as it initially started;
  • you can look for more valid options in the Monaco Editor's official documentation

Attributes

The attributes are divided in the groups:

  • Properties (Designer & Runtime)
    • these attributes usually have a direct impact on the component's behavior or presentation;
    • they're usually accessed through getters and setters on runtime;
  • OnInit (Designer)
    • these are methods called only during the initialization phase of the custom component
  • Runtime methods (Runtime)
    • These are methods specific to the custom component that are only available from the runtime
    • It excludes inherited methods (e.g.: getters and setters)

Properties

  • autoInit: boolean
    • On true, the monaco editor is automatically created as soon as the html rendering is completed. It uses the OnInit/monacoOptionsBuilder to acquire the options used for its creation;
    • It is a read-only property (does not have a getter/setter);
  • busy: boolean
    • same as in the sap.ui.core.Control busy property, getter and setter;
  • busyIndicatorDelay: number
    • same as in the sap.ui.core.Control busyIndicatorDelay property, getter and setter;​
  • busyIndicatorSize: sap.ui.core.BusyIndicatorSize
    • same as in the sap.ui.core.Control busyIndicatorSize property, getter and setter;​
  • height: sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • same as in the sap.m.FlexBox height property, getter and setter;
  • width: sap.ui.core.CSSSize
    • same as in the sap.m.FlexBox width property, getter and setter;
  • preferDOM: boolean
    • same as in the sap.ui.core.HTML preferDOM property, getter and setter;
  • styleClass, styleClassMargin and styleClassVisibility: String
    • these 3 properties work in the same way as the counterparts of any UI5 element in the Neptune DXP Designer;
    • they can be maintained during runtime through the hasStyleClass, addStyleClass and removeStyleClass methods;
  • visible: boolean
    • same as in the sap.ui.core.Control visible property, getter and setter.

OnInit

  • ​monacoOptionsBuilder

Runtime methods

This list does not refer to the properties getters and setters, as well as the style class methods. It is only related to the this component's specific methods.

  • onLoad(): Promise<empty>
    • It is fulfilled after the component is first rendered
  • onEditorCreated(): Promise<empty>
    • It is fulfilled when the editor is first created (either through initEditor or if the autoInit property is set to true)
  • initEditor(): Promise<monaco.editor>
    • It creates the monaco editor and resolves returning the created instance;
    • monacoOptionsBuildersetMonacoOptionsIt reads the properties for the initialization either from  or ;
    • If the editor exists already, then returns it directly through the promise without reading the properties or trying to create an editor instance;
  • getValue(): String
    • Gets the value of the editor's contents if the editor is created, or of the field 'value' of monacoOptions otherwise;
    • It can be used safely, even if the editor doesn't exist;
  • setValue( sValue: Any ): void
    • sValue is always converted to String using the following rules:
      • undefine becomes '';
      • null becomes '';
      • all other values are the result of String(sValue);
    • Sets the contents of the editor if it exists, or the of the field 'value' of monacoOptions otherwise;
    • It can be used safely, even if the editor doesn't exist:
      • In case it exists, it affects the editor's contents immediately;
      • otherwise it will store it in monacoOptions and read when the editor is created;
  • getLineCount(): number | NaN
    • Returns the total of line numbers within the editor
    • If the editor is not yet created, then it will return the total of lines on the text meant to be used during its initialization (if it is defined)
      • If no valid text is found, then there is no guarantee that it returns a number
  • getMonacoEditor(): null | monaco.editor
    • Returns the editor object if it exists;
    • Can be used to check whether the editor was created or not;
  • getMonacoOptions(): object
    • Returns the options for a monaco code editor creation;
    • Note that this value can be set even after the code editor has been created, so it is not guaranteed to be the same options used to create an already existing one;
  • setMonacoOptions(oMonacoOptions: object): void
    • Sets the monaco editor initialization options;
    • Use it before calling initEditor, if no options were set through monacoOptionsBuilder or if you wish to change them before creating the editor.

Technical information

This component is comprised of three UI5 objects: 

  • [ROOT] sap.m.VBox called Wrapper: {renderType: 'Bare'}
    • sap.ui.core.HTML called Content
    • sap.m.Button called OptionsBuilder: {visible: false}

When applied to an application, these components will respectively add the suffixes _Wrapper, _Content and _OptionsBuilder to the instance.

For example, if I want to create a javascript code editor called JsEditor on my app based on this component (ccmonacoeditor), then the app will generate an sap.m.VBox called JsEditor_Wrapper, an sap.ui.core.HTML calles JsEditor_Content and an sap.m.Button called JsEditor_OptionsBuilder. All these components are part of my JsEditor.

Important notes: 

  • The object JsEditor exists, but it is in fact the namespace related to this ccmonacoeditor instance I have on my app. You will only need to use JsEditor throughout your development;
  • When used together with a Launchpad, all the ids will have the prefix of the view (e.g.: __jsview1--JsEditor_Wrapper);
  • You cannot use sap.n.getObjectByID('JsEditor') or sap.ui.getCore().byId('__jsview1--JsEditor') to acquire the namespace JsEditor - it is not an UI5 object.

Use the Wrapper to define the dimensions of the component in your app (it's actually mapped to JsEditor-height and JsEditor-width).

The Content is initialized as a div with the same id  as Content.getId() (e.g.: __jsview1--JsEditor_Content) and occupies 100% height and width of its parent.

The OptionsBuilder is only used to hold the code for monacoOptionsBuilder. The code is mapped to the button's press event.

attribute.DESCRIPTION: Is the editor created automatically (true) or through code (false)?
return { language: 'javascript', ... } /* valid Monaco Editor's options. Only used during initialization. Required if autoInit is true. */

title: MonacoEditor
description: Code editor that can be added to an application. It requires the monaco editor library (shipped with Open Edition)
